articles.title: MAY 1989
articles.summary: This document outlines the San Jose Astronomical Association's (SJAA) calendar of events for May and June 1989. It details star parties at locations like Henry Coe State Park and Grant Ranch, general meetings featuring speakers like Bob Fingerhut on New Zealand astrophotography and Norm Sperling on the history of astronomy, and SJAA board meetings. The schedule also includes introductory observational astronomy classes, a public observing session, and notes on National Astronomy Day and the Riverside Telescope-Maker's Conference.

articles.title: FIELD OF VIEW
articles.summary: This article reports on the success of the 9th Annual SJAA/Bay Area Astronomical Auction and Swap Meet, with a detailed story to follow in the June issue of The Ephemeris. It also provides crucial information regarding reservations for the upcoming Yosemite Star Party, scheduled for June 30 - July 1, with bookings opening on May 13 at 10:00 am and a limit of 30 participants.

articles.title: MT. DIABLO INVITATIONAL
articles.summary: The Mt. Diablo Astronomical Society is hosting its first annual Invitational Star Party on Saturday, June 3rd. Attendees must contact Elmer Reeve in advance to register and pay a $5 fee, as gates will be closed and access will be restricted to preset times. This event promises a focused observing experience without casual traffic.

articles.title: WIDELY OBSERVED PARTIAL ECLIPSE OF THE SUN
articles.summary: The article reports on the widely observed partial solar eclipse on March 7th, noting that many, including both experienced observers and the general public, viewed the early morning event, often from their workplaces. Some observed it through morning fog, which acted as a natural filter, while others like Denise Hutson used proper solar filters and equipment (C90 telescope) to capture detailed sequences.

articles.title: OPEN HOUSE AT FREMONT PEAK OBSERVATORY
articles.summary: The Fremont Peak Observatory Association (FPOA) is hosting an open house on Saturday, May 6, for Bay Area amateur astronomers. This event will showcase the observatory's newly coated 30" telescope mirror and recent enhancements, aiming to improve the observing experience. It also serves as a pre-celebration for Astronomy Day on May 13.

articles.title: OUTSTANDING APRIL STAR PARTY AT THE PEAK
articles.summary: An "Outstanding April Star Party" at Fremont Peak State Park drew nearly 200 amateur astronomers who enjoyed a warm evening. Key highlights included a beautiful lunar conjunction with the Pleiades star cluster and observations of the strikingly red carbon star V Hydrae, which displayed varying colors through different telescopes. The event served to rekindle interest in amateur astronomy and highlighted overlooked celestial objects.

articles.title: MAY STARRY NIGHTS BY: RICHARD STANTON
articles.summary: Richard Stanton's "MAY STARRY NIGHTS" article provides a guide to astronomical observations for the month of May, immediately highlighting meteor showers. It specifically details the Phi Bootids, a lesser-known minor shower that reaches its maximum on May 1st and is active from April 16 through May 12.

articles.title: LUNAR PHASES
articles.summary: This document provides a tabular overview of the lunar phases for a specific period, detailing the time of each phase (New Moon, First Quarter, Full Moon, Last Quarter). For each phase, it lists the corresponding date, as well as the moon's rise, transit, and set times. It serves as a concise astronomical calendar for lunar events.

articles.title: NEARER PLANETS
articles.summary: This document provides astronomical data for the 'Nearer Planets' (Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn) across three dates in May. For each planet, it lists its distance in Astronomical Units (A.U.), apparent magnitude, and three specific times, likely indicating rise, transit, and set or observational windows. The data is presented for the 7th, 17th, and 27th of May.

articles.title: SOL
articles.summary: This document, titled "SOL," presents a structured log or schedule of astronomical observations. It lists specific celestial coordinates (Right Ascension and Declination) for three different objects, each paired with a date in May and three distinct times. This format suggests a plan or record of when certain sky regions were, or are intended to be, observed.

articles.title: ASTRONOMICAL TWILIGHT
articles.summary: This document provides a brief listing of Julian Dates and corresponding calendar dates with start and end times for astronomical twilight. It details these periods for specific days in May, showing the daily variation in twilight duration.

articles.title: SIDEREAL TIME
articles.summary: This article outlines a variety of astronomical events and observing opportunities for the month of May, providing details on Sidereal Time and several meteor showers, including the major Eta Aquarids. It also covers a lunar occultation of the star Upsilon Leonis, provides tracking information for bright minor planets like Vesta, Amphitrite, and Hygiea, and offers a "Deep Sky Challenge" to locate the elusive, interacting "Mice" galaxies in Coma Berenices. The content is tailored for amateur astronomers, including specific dates, times, magnitudes, and coordinates.

articles.title: ASTRO ADS
articles.summary: This document is a classifieds section, 'ASTRO ADS,' offering free listings for non-commercial astronomical products and services. It features numerous advertisements for various telescopes (Celestron C8s, Meade, a large apochromatic refractor), accessories like motor drives and mounts, and used astronomy publications. The section also provides contact information for ad submissions and sellers, and briefly mentions an FPOA open house event.

articles.title: ENDING THE SHAKES BY: JOHN GLEASON
articles.summary: John Gleason's article "ENDING THE SHAKES" reviews "Shake-Enders" foot pads from Epoch Instruments, presented as a crucial accessory to address the persistent problem of instability and lack of rigidity in portable telescope mounts. Despite advancements in high-tech telescope controls, the fundamental issue of a shaky mount remains, making these foot pads a noteworthy solution.

articles.title: PORTABLE TELESCOPES AND VIBRATION
articles.summary: This article discusses the persistent problem of image vibration in portable telescopes, attributing it to unstable mountings and tripods. It introduces a cost-effective solution, "Shake-Enders," a proprietary dampening material designed to absorb vibrations. Through personal experience and demonstrations, the author shows how this $60 product significantly reduces vibration dampening times, making observing and astrophotography more practical for various telescope setups.

articles.title: BY: DON MACHHOLZ
articles.summary: The article reports the recent discovery of two faint, periodic comets. Currently, there are no bright comets visible for observers in the Northern Hemisphere, indicating a quiet period for comet viewing.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Parker-Hartley (1989i)
articles.summary: Comet Parker-Hartley (1989i) was discovered by Quentin Parker and Malcolm Hartley at Siding Spring Observatory on March 2, 1989. Previously identified as a minor planet (1986 TF), its orbit was significantly altered by a close encounter with Jupiter in 1984. This interaction changed its path from a nearly circular 4.4 AU perihelion to an 8.9-year oval orbit with a 3.0 AU perihelion, having passed closest to the sun in August 1987 and now dimming.

articles.title: Periodic Comet Shoemaker-Holt 2 (1989i)
articles.summary: Periodic Comet Shoemaker-Holt 2 (1989i) was discovered on March 9 by Carolyn and Eugene Shoemaker, and Henry Holt using the 18" Schmidt at Mt. Palomar. It has an orbital period of 7.8 years, was magnitude 13 at discovery, and reached perihelion at 2.70 AU last September.

articles.title: SEEKING COMETS
articles.summary: This article analyzes the discovery time of 45 visually found comets between 1975 and 1988 relative to their perihelion. It reveals that evening sky comets are typically discovered much earlier before perihelion (27.8 days) compared to morning sky comets (5.4 days), primarily because evening comets have yet to reach the solar vicinity. A brief examination of orbital direction (direct vs. retrograde) showed minimal difference in discovery timing.

articles.title: OBSERVING FROM THE PINNACLES BY EDWARD L. HILLYER
articles.summary: Edward L. Hillyer evaluates Pinnacles, specifically the West Pinnacles area near the entrance, as a superior astronomical observing site compared to Fremont Peak. He highlights its darker skies, minimal sky-glow, and lack of summer fog, which allow for excellent views of deep-sky objects and the Milky Way. The article also provides detailed directions to this preferred 1,700 ft. elevation observing spot.

articles.title: THINKING BIG: THE GROUP 70 TELESCOPE PROJECT BY: JOHN W. BRIGGS
articles.summary: Group 70, an amateur astronomy organization in the San Francisco Bay area, is undertaking the ambitious project of building and operating a 72-inch computer-controlled altazimuth telescope. They successfully raised over $30,000 to acquire a 72-inch Pyrex mirror blank and plan for remote-access observing, making the instrument available for both amateur research and professional collaborations. Driven by the expertise of amateur telescope makers, engineers, and scientists, the project emphasizes community involvement, innovative technology, and a structured, 'pay-as-you-go' approach to ensure its success.

articles.title: GENERAL MEETINGS
articles.summary: The SJAA holds monthly General Meetings at the Red Cross building in Los Gatos, California, featuring guest speakers on various astronomical topics and informal "Indoor Star Parties." These meetings cater to a wide range of interests, from astrophotography to telescope making, in a friendly atmosphere. Detailed directions, time (8 PM), and date (1st Saturday of each month) for the meetings are provided.

articles.title: INDOOR STAR PARTIES
articles.summary: The article describes "Indoor Star Parties," informal Saturday evening gatherings for amateur astronomers to socialize, discuss astronomy, and share equipment. These events often feature telescope observations in the parking lot, astrophotography slideshows, club board meetings, and an introductory astronomy workshop. Members are encouraged to bring their telescopes and accessories to share with the group.

articles.title: FIELD EXPEDITIONS
articles.summary: The SJAA organizes "Star Parties" for astronomical observation on Saturdays near the New Moon. These events are held at various locations, ranging from sites close to San Jose to destinations as far as Yosemite National Park. Participants are advised to consult the EPHEMERIS for specific star party locations.

articles.title: FREMONT PEAK STATE PARK
articles.summary: Fremont Peak State Park is a highly popular observing location for Bay Area amateur astronomers, known for serious deep sky observing and astrophotography during New Moon weekends. Located near San Juan Bautista, it attracts 50-100 telescopes during summer months, with the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA) often setting up in Coulter Camp. The article also provides contact information for the SJAA's officers and board of directors.

articles.title: SAN JOSE ASTRONOMICAL ASSOCIATION MEMBERSHIP APPLICATION
articles.summary: This document is a membership application form for the San Jose Astronomical Association (SJAA). It outlines different membership types—Membership Only, Membership/SAT, and Junior (under 18)—along with their respective fees, and provides instructions for submitting the application and payment. Contact information for the treasurer and details for the SJAA Ephemeris are also included.
